The narrator is bemoaning that part of the human condition is being blind to our shortcomings, flaws and corruption that is inevitable in the material world. Sometimes we need an external voice from a friend or a song like this to articulate what is hidden within ourselves.
While my guitar gently weeps

This song also represents a return from the sitar to the guitar. Since finding a sitar on the set of Help!, George had become enthralled in learning the instrument. He then realizes that all this time, he has left his growing process in the guitar for something he only thought was more mature/evolved.

Harrison not only had Clapton play on the song because of their friendship but also for other reasons. He knew that the presence of Clapton would quit the fighting and bickering of the other members. Also, Harrison felt like it would not be right for himself to play the lead after his lack of recent commitment to the instrument.

An early “demo” version of this song (included on the Beatles' album “Anthology Vol.3”) had a different set of lyrics at this point:

I look from the wings at the play you are staging,
While my guitar gently weeps
As I’m sitting here, doing nothing but ageing,
Still, my guitar gently weeps

This set of lyrics brings focus to the meaning of the unexpectedly mundane “I see it needs sweeping” line in the 1st verse. George is chastising himself for being distracted by the mundane, standing backstage instead of “acting” to help change the attitudes of others.

Despite replacing the majority of these lyrics with something more universal, it seems Harrison took this personal chastisement to heart, by devoting himself to aiding others. He took up many charitable causes, most famously “the Concert for Bangladesh” in 1971.

Someone Harrison used to admire has been corrupted by the materialistic lifestyle that naturally comes along with being a rockstar.

In Martin Scorsese’s documentary George Harrison: Living In A Material World, Harrison’s friends (including Paul McCartney and Ringo) claim that it was the opulent lifestyle and the privileges that being a Beatle afforded him that made Harrison turn to Eastern Spiritual philosophies to find meaning in his life.
I look at the floor, and I see it needs sweeping

An odd line compared to the deep and powerful lines surrounding it. It provides a stark contrast to the heavy-handed, epic metaphors like “looking at the world” and “looking at you all”, and instead provides a personal and more down-to-earth feel to the song.

However, an early alternate set of lyrics to a later verse brings some light to the meaning of this line. Harrison was lamenting the fact that he gets distracted from the bigger issues by the mundane cares of life.

I look at you all, see the love there that’s sleeping
 While my guitar gently weeps

Harrison sees the harmony that society is capable of achieving, but laments the fact that people won’t “wake up” and love each other.

This song is spiritually aligned with Harrison’s Eastern philosophy and his Within You Without You defining work as a songwriter where he recognizes, “with our love we could save the world, if they only knew.” Here George brings back that philosophy while fully integrating it into a more blues-based song structure. The weeping guitar, as noted in other annotations, is played by his friend, Eric Clapton.
